translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Easily have the living drops, made beautiful, approached the lake, Yea, to the place of sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Compass about, our faithful Friend, all our possessions with thy might: Guard, hero like, our sheltering home.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Loud neighs the Courser Etaśa, with singers, harnessed for the place, Guided for travel to the lake.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What time the Swift One resteth in the golden place of sacrifice, He leaves the foolish far away.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The friends have sung in unison, the prudent wish to sacrifice: Down sink the unintelligent.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For Indra girt by Maruts, flow, thou Indu, very rich in sweets, To sit in place of sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Controlling priests and sages skilled in holy song adorn thee well: The living make thee beautiful.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Aryaman, Mitra, Varuṇa drink Pavamana's juice, yea, thine: O Sage, the Maruts drink thereof.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Soma, Indu, thou while thou art purified urgest onward speech. Thousandfold, with the lore of hymns.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Yea, Soma, Indu, while thou art purified do thou bring to us Speech thousandfold that longs for war.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indu, Much-invoked, while thou art purifying, as the Friend. Of these men enter thou the lake.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bright are these Somas blent with milk, with light that flashes brilliantly. And form that utters loud acclaim.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Led by his drivers, and sent forth, the Strong Steed hath come nigh for spoil, Like warriors when they stand arrayed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Specially, Soma, coming as a Sage from heaven to prosper us, Flow like the Sun for us to see. Next: HYMN LXV. Soma Pavamana.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THE, glittering maids send Sūra forth, the glorious sisters, close-allied, Send Indu forth, their mighty Lord.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Pervade, O Pavamana, all our treasures with repeated light, God, coming hither from the Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Pour on us, Pavamana, rain, as service and rain praise for Gods: Pour all to be our nourishment.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou art a Steer by lustre: we, O Pavamana, faithfully Call upon thee the Splendid One.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Do thou, rejoicing, nobly-armed! pour upon us heroic strength: O Indu, come thou bitherward.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When thou art cleansed with both the hands and dipped in waters, with the wood. Thou comest to the gathering-place.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sing forth your songs, as Vyaśva sang, to Soma Pavamana, to, The Mighty One with thousand eyes;

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whose coloured sap they drive with stones, the yellow meath-distilling juice, Indu for Indra, for his drink.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We seek to gain the friendly love of thee that Strong and Mighty One, Of thee the winner of all wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Flow onward with thy stream, a Steer, inspiriting the Maruts’ Lord, Winning all riches by thy might.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: I send thee forth to battle from the press, O Pavamana, Strong, Sustainer, looker on the light.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Acknowledged by this song of mine, flow, tawny-coloured, with thy stream Incite to battle thine ally.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indu, visible to all pour out for us abundant food: Soma, be thou our prosperer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The pitchers, Indu, with thy streams have sung aloud in vigorous might Enter them, and let Indra drink.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O thou whose potent gladdening juice they milk out with the stones, flow on, Destroyer of our enemies.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: King Pavamana is implored with holy songs, on man's behalf, To travel through the firmament.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bring us, O Indu, hundredfold increase of kine, and noble steeds, The gift of fortune for our help.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Pressed for the banquet of the Gods, O Soma, bring us might, and speed, Like beauty for a brilliant show.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Soma, flow on exceeding bright with loud roar to the wooden vats, Falcon-like resting in thine home.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Soma, the Water-winner flows to Indra, Vāyu, Varuṇa, To Viṣṇu and the Marut host.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Soma , bestowing food upon our progeny, from every sides, Pour on us riches thousandfold

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Soma juices which have been expressed afar or near at hand, Or there on Śaryaṇāvān's bank,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Those pressed among Arjikas, pressed among the active, in men's homes, Or pressed among the Races Five-

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May these celestial drops, expressed, pour forth upon us, as they flow, Rain from the heavens apd hero strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Urged forward o’er the ox-hide flows the Lovely One of tawny hue, Lauded by Jamadagni's song.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like horses urged to speed, the drops, bright, stirring vital power, when blent With milk, are beautified in streams.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So they who toil with juices send thee forward for the Gods’ repast: So with this splendour flow thou on.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We choose to-day that chariot-steed of thine, the Strong, that brings us bliss, The Guardian, the desire of all,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Excellent, the Gladdener, the Sage with heart that understands, The Guardian, the desire of all;

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Who for ourselves, O thou Most Wise, is wealth and fair intelligence, The Guardian, the desire of all. Next: HYMN LXVI. Soma Pavamana.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: FOR holy lore of every sort, flow onward thou whom all men love. A Friend to be besought by friends.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O'er all thou rulest with these Two which, Soma Pavamana, stand, Turned, as thy stations, hitherward.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Wise Soma Pavamana, thou encompassest on every side Thy stations as the seasons come.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Flow onward, generating food, for precious boons of every kind, A Friend for friends, to be our help.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Upon the lofty ridge of heaven thy bright rays with their essences, Soma, spread purifying power.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Soma, these Seven Rivers flow, as being thine, to give command: The Streams of milk run forth to thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Flow onward, Soma in a stream, effused to gladden Indra's heart, Bringing imperishable fame.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Driving thee in Vivasvān's course, the Seven Sisters with their hymns Made melody round thee the Sage.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The virgins deck thee o’er fresh streams to drive thee to the sieve when thou, A singer, bathest in the wood.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The streams of Pavamana, thine, Sage, Mighty One, have pouredthem forth. Like coursers eager for renown.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They have been poured upon the fleece towards the meath-distilling vat: The holy songs have sounded forth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like milch-kine coming home, the drops of Soma juice have reached the lake, Have reached the place of sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indu, to our great delight the running waters flow to us, When thou wilt robe thyself in milk.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In this thy friendship, and with thee to help us, fain to sacrifice, Indu, we crave thy friendly love.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Flow on, O Soma, for the great Viewer of men, for gain of Idne Enter thou into Indra's throat.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Best art thou, Soma, of the great, Strongest of strong ones, Indu: thou As Warrior ever hast prevailed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Mightier even than the strong, more valiant even than the brave, More libpral than the bountiful,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Soma, as Sūra, bring us food, win offspring of our bodies: we Elect thee for our friendship, we elect thee for companionship.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni, thou pourest life; send down upon us food and vigorous strength; Drive thou misfortune far away,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Agni is Pavamana, Sage, Chief Priest of all the Races Five: To him whose wealth is great we pray.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Skilled in thy task, O Agni, pour splendour with hero strength on us, Granting me wealth that nourishes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Beyond his enemies away to sweet praise Pavamana flows, Like Sūrya visible to all.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Adorned by living men, set forth for entertainment, rich in food, Far-sighted Indu is a Steed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He, Pavamana, hath produced the lofty Law, the brilliant light, Destroying darkness black of hue.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: From tawny Pavamana, the Destroyer, radiant streams have sprung, Quick streams from him whose gleams are swift.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Best rider of the chariot, praised with fairest praise mid beauteous ones, Gold-gleaming with the Marut host,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May Pavamana, best to win the booty, penetrate with rays, Giving the singer hero strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Over the fleecy sieve hath flowed the drop effused: to Indra comes Indu while he is purified

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This Soma, through the pressing-stones, is sporting on the oxhide, and Summoning Indra to the draught.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Pavamana, bless us, so that we may live, with that bright milk Of thine which hath been brought from heaven. Next: HYMN LXVII. Soma and Others.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THOU, Soma, hast a running stream, joyous, most strong at sacrifice: Flow bounteously bestowing wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Effused as cheerer of the men, flowing best gladdener, thou art A Prince to Indra with thy juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Poured forth by pressing-stones, do thou with loud roar send us in a stream Most excellent illustrious might.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indu, urged forward, floweth through the fleecy cloth: the Tawny One With his loud roar hath brought as strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indu, thou flowest through the fleece, bringing felicities and fame, And, Soma, spoil and wealth in kine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hither, O Indu, bring us wealth in steeds and cattle hundredfold: Bring wealth, O Soma, thousandfold.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In purifying, through the sieve the rapid drops of'Soma juice Come nigh to Indra in their course.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For Indra floweth excellent Indu, the noblest Soma juice The Living for the Living One.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The glittering maids send Sūra forth they with their song have sung aloud To Pavamana dropping meath.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May Pūṣan, drawn by goats, be our protector, and on all his paths Bestow on us our share of maids.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This Soma flows like gladdening oil for him who wears the braided locks: He shall give us our share of maids.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This Soma juice, O glowing God, flows like pure oil, effused for thee: He shall give us our share of maids.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Flow onward, Soma, in thy stream, begetter of the sages' speech: Wealth-giver among Gods art thou.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Falcon dips within the jars: he wrapḥim in his robe and goes Loud roaring to the vats of wood.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Soma, thy juice hath been effused and poured into the pitcher: like A rapid hawk it rushes on.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For Indra flow most rich in sweets, O Soma, bringing him delight.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They were sent forth to feast the Gods, like chariots that display their strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Brilliant, best givers of delight, these juices have sent Vāyu forth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bruised by the press-stones and extolled, Soma, thou goest to the sieve, Giving the worshipper hero strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This juice bruised by the pressing-stones and lauded passes through the sieve, Slayer of demons, through the fleece.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Pavamana, drive away the danger, whether near at hand Or far remote, that finds me here.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This day may Pavamana cleanse us with his purifying power, Most active purifying Priest.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Agni, with the cleansing light diffused through all thy fiery glow, Purify thou this prayer of ours.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Cleanse us with thine own cleansing power, O Agni, that is bright with flame, And by libations poured to thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Savitar, God, by both of these, libation, purifying power, Purify me on every side.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Cleanse us, God Savitar, with Three, O Soma, with sublimest forms, Agni, with forms of power and might.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May the Gods’ company make me clean, and Vasus make rue pure by song. Purify me, ye General Gods; O Jātavedas, make me pure.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Fill thyself full of juice, flow forth, O Soma, thou with all thy stalks, The best oblation to the Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We with our homage have approached the Friend who seeks our wondering praise, Young, strengthener of the solemn rite.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Lost is Alayya's axe. O Soma, God do thou send it back hither in thy flow Even, Soma, God, if ’twere a mole.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The man who reads the essence stored by saints, the Pavamani hymns, Tastes food completely purified, made sweet by Mātariśvan's touch.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whoever reads the essence stored by saints, the Pavamani hymns, Sarasvatī draws forth for him water and butter, milk and meath. Next: HYMN LXVIII. Soma Pavamana.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THE drops of Soma juice like cows who yield their milk have flowed forth, rich in meath, unto the Shining One, And, seated on the grass, raising their voice, assumed the milk, the covering robe wherewith the udders stream.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He bellows with a roar arourd the highest twigs: the Tawny One is sweetened as he breaks them up. Then passing through the sieve into the ample room, the God throws off the dregs according to his wish.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The gladdening drink that measured out the meeting Twins fills full with milk the Eternal Ever-waxing Pair. Bringing to light the Two great Regions limitless, moving above them he gained sheen that never fades.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Wandering through, the Parents, strengthening the floods, the Sage makes his place swell with his own native might. The stalk is mixed with grain: he comes led by the men together with the sisters, and preserves the Head.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With energetic intellect the Sage is born, deposited as germ of Law, far from the Twins. They being young at first showed visibly distinct the Creature that is half-concealed and half-exposed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The sages knew the form of him the Gladdener, what time the Falcon brought the plant from far away. Him who assures success they beautified in streams, the stalk who yearned therefor, mighty and meet for praise.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Together with the Ṛṣis, with their prayers and hymns ten women deck thee, Soma, friendly when effused. Led by the men, with invocations of the Gods, through the fleece, thou hast given us strength to win the spoil.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Songs resonant with praise have celebrated him. Soma, Friend, springing forth with his fair company. Even him who rich in meath, with undulating stream, Winnner of Wealth, Immortal, sends his voice from heaven,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He sends it into all the region forth from heaven. Soma, while he is filtcred, settles in the jars. With milk and waters is he decked when pressed with stones: Indu, when purified, shall find sweet rest and room.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Even thus poured forth How on thy way, O Soma, vouchsafing us most manifold lively vigour. We will invoke benevolent Earth and Heaven. Give us, ye Gods, riches with noble heroes. Next: HYMN LXIX. Soma Pavamana.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: LAID like an arrow on the bow the hymn hath been loosed like a young calf to the udder of its dam. As one who cometh first with full stream she is milked the Soma is impelled to this man's holy rites.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The thought is deeply fixed; the savoury juice is shed; the tongue with joyous sound is stirring in the mouth; And Pavamana, like the shout of combatants, the drop rising in sweet juice, is flowing through the fleece.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He flows about the sheep-skin, longing for a bride: he looses Aditi's Daughters for the worshipper. The sacred drink hath come, gold-tinted, well-restrained: like a strong Bull he shines, whetting his manly might.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Bull is bellowing; the Cows are coming nigh: the Goddesses approach the God's own resting-place. Onward hath Soma passed through the sheep's fair bright fleece, and hath, as ’twere, endued a garment newly washed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The golden-hued, Immortal, newly bathed, puts on a brightly shining vesture that is never harmed. He made the ridge of heaven to be his radiant robe, by sprinkling of the bowls from moisture of the sky.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Even as the beams of Sūrya, urging men to speed, that cheer and send to sleep, together rush they forth, These swift outpourings in long course of holy rites: no form save only Indra shows itself so pure.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As down the steep slope of a river to the vale, drawn from the Steer the swift strong draughts have found a way. Well be it with the men and cattle in our home. May powers, O Soma, may the people stay with us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Pour out upon us wealth in goods, in gold, in steeds, in cattle and in corn, and great heroic strength. Ye, Soma, are my Fathers, lifted up on high as heads of heaven and makers of the strength of life.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These Pavamanas here, these drops of Soma, to Indra have sped forth like cars to booty. Effused, they pass the cleansing fleece, while, gold-hued, they cast their covering off to pour the rain down.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indu, flow thou on for lofty Indra, flow blameless, very gracious, foe-destroyer. Bring splendid treasures to the man who lauds thee. O Heaven and Earth, with all the Gods protect. us. Next: HYMN LXX. Soma Pavamana.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THE three times seven Milch-kine in the eastern heaven have for this Soma poured the genuine milky draught. Four other beauteous Creatures hath he made for his adornment, when he waxed in strength through holy rites.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Longing for lovely Amṛta, by his wisdom he divided, each apart from other, earth and heaven. He gladly wrapped himself in the most lucid floods, when through their glory they found the God's resting-place.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May those his brilliant rays he ever free from death, inviolate, for both classes of created things,— Rays wherewith powers of men and Gods are purified. Yea, even for this have sageswelcomed him as King.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He, while he is adorned by the ten skilful ones, that he too in the Midmost Mothers may create, While he is watching o’er the lovely Amṛta's ways, looks on both races as Beholder of mankind.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He, while he is adorned to stream forth mighty strength, rejoices in his place between the earth and heaven. The Steer dispels the evil-hearted with his might, aiming at offerings as an archer at the game.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Beholding, as it were, Two Mother Cows, the Steer goes roaring on his way even as the Maruts roar. Knowing Eternal Law, the earliest light of heaven, he, passing wise, was chosen out to tell it forth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The fearful Bull is bellowing with violent might, far-sighted, sharpening his yellowcoloured horns. Soma assumes his seat in the well-fashioned place: the cowhide and the sheepskin are his ornament.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bright, making pure his body free from spot and stain, on the sheep's back the Golden-coloured hath flowed down. Acceptable to Mitra, Vāyu, Varuṇa, he is prepared as threefold meal by skilful men.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Flow on for the God's banquet, Soma, as a Steer, and enter Indra's heart, the Soma's reservoir. Bear us beyond misfortune ere we be oppres. sed. the man who knows the land directs the man who asks.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Urged like a car-steed flow to strength, O Soma: Indu, flow onward to the throat of Indra. Skilled, bear us past, as in a boat o’er water: as battling Hero save us from the foeman. Next: HYMN LXXI. Soma Pavamana,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THE guerdon is bestowed: the Mighty takes his Seat, and, ever-Watchful, guards from fiend and evil sprite. Gold-hued, he makes the cloud his diadem, the milk his carpet in both worlds, and prayer his robe of state.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Strong, bellowing, he goes, like one who slays the folk; he lets this hue of Asuras flow off from him, Throws off his covering, seeks his father's meeting-place, and thus makes for himself the bright robe he assumes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Onward he flows, from both the hands, pressed out with stones: excited by the prayer, the water makes him wild. He frolics and draws near, completes his work with song, and bathes in streams to satisfy the worshipper.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They pour out meath around the Master of the house, Celestial Strengthener of the mountain that gives might; In whom, through his great powers, oblation-eating cows in their uplifted udder mix their choicest milk.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They, the ten sisters, on the lap of Aditi, have sent him forward like a car from both the arms. He wanders and comes near the Cow's mysterious place, even the place which his inventions have produced.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like as a falcon to his home, so speeds the God to his own golden wisely-tashioned place to rest. With song they urge the darling to the sacred grass: the Holy One goes like a courser to the Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: From far away, from heaven, the redhued noted Sage, Steer of the triple height, hath sung unto the kine. With thousand guidings he, leading this way and that, shines, as a singer, splendidly through many a morn.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: His covering assumes a radiant hue; where’er he comes into the fight he drives the foe afar. The Winner of the Floods, with food he seeks the host of heaven, he comes to praises glorified with milk.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like a bull roaming round the herds he bellows: he hath assumed the brilliancy of Sūrya. Down to the earth hath looked the heavenly Falcon: Soma with wisdom views all living creatures. Next: HYMN LXXII. Soma Pavamana.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THEY cleanse the Gold-hued: like a red Steed is he yoked, and Soma in the jar is mingled with the milk. He sendeth out his voice, and many loving friends of him the highly lauded hasten with their songs.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The many sages utter words in unison, while into Indra's throat they pour the Soma juice, When, with the ten that dwell together closely joined, the men whose hands are skilful cleanse the lovely meath.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He goes upon his way, unresting, to the cows, over the roaring sound which Sarya's Daughter loves. The Falcon brought it to him for his own delight: now with the twofold kindred sisters is his home.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Washed by the men, stone-pressed, dear on the holy grass, faithful to seasons, Lord of cattle from of old, Most liberal, completing sacrifice for men, O Indra, pure bright Soma, Indu, flows for thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indra, urged by arms of men and poured in streams, Soma flows on for thee afterḥis Godlike kind. Plans thou fulfillest, gatherest thoughts for sacrifice: in the bowls sits the Gold-hued like a roosting bird.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sages well-skilled in work, intelligent, drain out the stalk that roars, the Sage, the Everlasting One. The milk, the hymns unite them with him in the place of sacrifice, his seat who is produced anew.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Earth's central point, sustainer of the mighty heavens, distilled into the streams, into the waters' wave, As Indra's thunderbolt, Steer with farspreading wealth, Soma is flowing on to make the heart rejoice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Over the earthly region flow thou on thy way, helping the praiser and the pourer, thou Most Wise. Let us not lack rich treasure reaching to our home, and may we clothe ourselves in manifold bright wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hither, O Indu, unto us a hundred gifts of steeds, a thousand gifts of cattle and of gold, Measure thou forth, yea, splendid ample strengthening food do thou, O Pavamana, heed this laud of ours. Next: HYMN LXXIII. Soma Pavamana.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THEY from the spouting drop have sounded at the rim: naves speed together to the place of sacrifice. That Asura hath formed, to seize, three lofty heights. The ships of truth have borne the pious man across.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The strong Steers, gathering, have duly stirred themselves,and over the stream's wave the friends sent forth the song. Engendering the hymn, with flowing streams of meath, Indra's dear body have they caused to wax in strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With sanctifying gear they sit around the song: their ancient Father guards their holy work from harm. Varuṇa hath o’erspread the mighty sea of air. Sages had power to hold him in sustaining floods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sweet-tongued, exhaustless, they have sent their voices down togetlier, in heaven's vault that pours a thousand streams. His wildly-restless warders never close an eye: in every place are found the bonds that bind man last.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O'er Sire and Mother they have roared in unison bright with the verse of praise, burning up riteless men, Blowing away with supernatural might from earth and from the heavens the swarthy skin which Indra hates.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Those which, as guides of song and counsellors of speed, were manifested from their ancient dwelling place,— From these the eyeless and the deaf have turned aside: the wicked travel not the pathway of the Law.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What time the filter with a thousand streams is stretched, the thoughtful sages purify their song therein. Bright-coloured are their spies, vigorous, void of guile, excellent, fair to see, beholders of mankind.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Guardian of Law, most wise, he may not be deceived: three Purifiers hath he set within his heart. With wisdom he beholds all creatures that exist: he drives into the pit the hated riteliess ones.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The thread of sacrifice spun in the cleansing sieve, on Varuṇa's tongue-tip, by supernatural might,— This, by their striving, have the prudent ones attained: he who hath not this power shall sink into the pit. Next: HYMN LXXIV. Soma Pavamana

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: BORN like a youngling he hath clamoured in the wood, when he, the Red, the Strong, would win the light of heaven. He comes with heavenly seed that makes the water swell: him for wide-spreading shelter we implore with prayer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: A far-extended pillar that supports the sky the Soma-stalk, filled full, moves itself every way. He shall bring both these great worlds while the rite proceeds: the Sage holds these who move! together and all food.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Wide space hath he who follows Aditi's right path, and mighty, well-made food, meath blent with Soma juice; He who from hence commands the rain, Steer of the kine, Leader of floods, who helps us hence, who claims our laud.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Butter and milk are drawn from animated cloud; thence Amṛta is produced, centre of sacrifice. Hini the Most Bounteous Ones, ever united, love; him as ouir Friend the Men who make all swell rain down.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Soma-stalk hath roared, following with the wave: he swells with sap for man the skin which Gods enjoy. Upon the lap of Aditi he lays the germ, by means whereof we gain children and progeny.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In the third region which distils a thousand streams, may the Exhaustless Ones descend with procreant power. The kindred Four have been sent downward from the heavens: dropping with oil they bring Amṛta and sacred gifts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Soma assumes white colour when he strives to gain: the bounteous Asura knows full many a precious boon. Down the steep slope, through song, he comes to sacrifice, and he will burst the water-holding cask of heaven,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Yea, to the shining milk-anointed beaker, as to his goal, hath stepped the conquering Courser. Pious-souled men have sent their giffi of cattle unto Kakṣīvān of the hundred winters.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Soma, thy juice when thou art blended with the streams, flows, Pavamana, through the long wool of the sheep. So, cleansed by sages. O best giver of delight, grow sweet for Indra, Pavamana! for his drink. Next: HYMN LXXV. Soma Pavamana.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: GRACIOUSLY-MINDED he is flowing on his way to win dear names o’er which the Youthful One grows great. The Mighty and Far-seeing One hath mounted now the mighty Sūrya's car which moves to every side.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Speaker, unassailable Master of this hymn, the Tongue of sacrifice pours forth the pleasant meath. Within the lustrous region of the heavens the Son makes the third secret name of Mother and of Sire.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sending forth flashes he hath bellowed to the jars, led by the men into the golden reservoir. The milky streams of sacrifice have sung to him: he of the triple height shines brightly through the morns.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Pressed by the stones, with hymns, and graciously inclined, illuminating both the Parents, Heaven and Earth, He flows in ordered season onward through the flee, a current of sweet juice still swelling day by day.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Flow onward, Soma, flow to bring prosperity: cleansed by the men, invest thee with the milky draught. What gladdening drinks thou hast, foaming, exceeding strong, even with these incite Indra to give us wealth. Next: HYMN LXXVI. Soma Pavamana.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: ON flows the potent juice, sustainer of the heavens, the strength of Gods, whom men must hail with shouts of joy. The Gold-hued, started like a courser by brave men, impetuously winneth splendour in the streams.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He takes his weapons, like a hero, in his hands, fain to win light, car-borne, in forays for the kine. Indu, while stimulating India's might, is urged forward and balmed by sages skilful in their task.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Soma, as thou art purified with flowing wave, exhibiting thy strength enter thou Indra's throat. Make both worlds stream for us, as lightning doth the clouds: mete out exhaustless powers for us, as ’twere through song.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Onward he flows, the King of all that sees the light: the Ṛṣis’ Lord hath raised the song of sacrifice; Even he who is adorned with Sūrya's arrowy beam, Father of hymns, whose wisdom is beyond our reach.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like as a bull to herds, thou flowest to the pail, bellowing as a steer upon the water's lap. So, best of Cheerers, thou for Indra flowest on that we, with thy protection, may o’ercome in fight. Next: HYMN LXXVII. Soma Pavamana.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: MORE beauteous than the beautiful, as Indra's bolt, this Soma, rich in sweets, hath clamoured in the vat. Dropping with oil, abundant, streams of sacrifice flow unto him like milch-kine, lowing, with their milk.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: On flows that Ancient One whom, hitherward, from heaven, sped through the region of the air, the Falcon snatched. He, quivering with alarm and terrified in heart before bow-armed Kṛśānu, holdeth fast the sweet.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May those first freshest drops of Soma juice effused flow on, their way to bring us mighty strength in kine. Beauteous as serpents, worthy to be looked upon, they whom each sacred gift and all our prayers have pleased.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May that much-lauded Indu, with a heart inclined to us, well-knowing, fight against our enemies. He who hath brought the germ beside the Strong One's seat moves onward to the widely-opcned stall of kine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The active potent juice of heaven is flowing on, great Varuṇa whom the forward man can ne’er deceive. Mitra, the Holy, hath been pressed for troubled times, neighing like an impatient horse amid the herd, Next: HYMN LXXVIII. Soma Pavamana.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: RAISING his voice the King hath flowed upon his way: invested with the waters he would win the kine. The fleece retains his solid parts as though impure, and bright and cleansed he seeks the special place of Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, Soma, art effused for Indra by the men, balmed in the wood as wave, Sage, Viewer of mankind. Full many are the paths whereon thou mayest go: a thousand bay steeds hast thou resting in the bowls.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Apsarases who dwell in waters of the sea, sitting within, have flowed to Soma wise of heart. They urge the Master of the house upon his way, and to the Eternal Pavamana pray for bliss.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Soma flows on for u's as winner of the kine, winner of thousands, cars, water, and light, and gold; He whom the Gods have made a gladdening draught to drink, the drop most sweet to taste, weal-bringing, red of hue.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Soma, as Pavamana thou, our faithful Friend, making for us these real treasures, flowest on. Slay thou the enemy both near and,far away: grant us security and ample pasturage. Next: HYMN LXXIX. Soma Pavamana.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: SPONTANEOUS let our drops of Soma juice flow on, pressed, golden-hued, among the Gods of lofty heaven. Perish among us they who give no gifts of food! perish the godless! May our prayers obtain success.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Forward to us the drops, distilling meath, shall flow, like riches for whose sake we urge the horses on. Beyond the crafty hindering of all mortal men may we continually bear precious wealth away.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Yea, yerily, foe of hate shown to himself is he, yea, verity, destroyer too of other hate. As thirst subdueth in the desert, conquer thou, O Soma Pavarnana, men of evil thoughts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Near kin to thee is he, raised loftiest in the heavens: upon the earth's high ridge thy scions have grown forth. The press-stones chew and crunch thee on the ox's hide: sages have milked thee with their hands into the streams.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So do they hurry on thy strong and beauteous juice, O Indu, as the first ingredient of the draught. Bring low, thou Pavamana, every single foe, and be thy might shown forth as sweet and gladdening drink. Next: HYMN LXXX. Soma Pavamana.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: ON flows the stream of Soma who beholds mankind: by everlasting Law he calls the Gods from heaven. He lightens with the roaring of Br aspati: h the lakes have not contained the pourings of juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, powerful Soma, thou to whom the cows have -lowed, ascendest bright with sheen, thine iron-fashioned home. Thou, lengthening our princes' life and high renown, flowest for Indra as his might to gladdening drink.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Best giver of delight, he flows to Indra's throat, robing himself in might, Auspicious One, for fame. He spreads himself abroad to meet all things that be: the vigorous Tawny Steed flows sporting on his way.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The men, the ten swift fingers, milk thee out for Gods, even thee most rich in meath, with thousand flowing streams. Soma who winnest thousands, driven by the men, expressed with stones, bring, as thou flowest, all the Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Deft-handed men with stones, the ten swift fingers, drain thee into waters, thee, the Steer enriched with sweets. Thou, Soma, gladdening Indra, and the Heavenly Host, flowest as Pavamana like a river's wave. Next: HYMN LXXXI. Soma Pavamana.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: ONWARD to Indra's throat move, beauteously adorned, the waves of Soma as he purifies himself, When they, brought forward with the lovely curd of kine, effused, have cheered the Hero to bestow his gifts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hither hath Soma flowed unto the beakers, like a chariot-horse, a stallion swift upon his way. Thus, knowing both the generations, he obtains the rights and dues of Gods from yonder and from hence.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: While thou art cleansed, O Soma, scatter wealth on us; Indu, bestow great bounty as a liberal Prince. Giver of life, with wisdom help to opulence; strew not our home possessions far away from us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hither let Pūṣan Pavamana come to us, Varuṇa, Mitra, bountiful, of one accord, The Maruts, Aśvins, Vāyu, and Bṛhaspati, Savitar, Tvaṣṭar, tractable Sarasvatī.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Both Heaven and Earth, the all-invigorating Pair, Vidhatar, Aditi, and Aryaman the God, Bhaga who blesses men, the spacious Firmament,—let all the Gods in Pavamana take delight. Next: HYMN LXXXII. Soma Pavamana.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: EVEN as a King hath Soma, red and tawny Bull, been pressed: the Wondrous One hath bellowed to the kine. While purified he passes through the filtering fleece to seat him hawk-like on the place that drops with oil.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To glory goest thou, Sage with disposing skill, like a groomed steed thou rusbest forward to the prize. O Soma, be thou gracious, driving off distress: thou goest, clothed in butter, to a robe of state.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Parjanya is the Father of the Mighty Bird: on mountains, in earth's centre hath he made his home. The waters too have flowed, the Sisters, to the kine: he meets the pressing-stones at the beloved rite.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou givest pleasure as a wife delights her lord. Listen, O Child of Pajri, for to thee I speak. Amid the holy songs go on that we may live: in time of trouble, Soma, watch thou free from blame.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As to the men of old thou camest, Indu unharmed, to strengthen, winning hundreds, thousands, So now for new felicity flow onward: the waters follow as thy law ordaineth. Next: HYMN LXXXIII. Soma Pavamana.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: SPREAD is thy cleansing filter, Brahmaṇaspati: as Prince, thou enterest its limbs from every side. The raw, whose mass hath not been heated gains not this: they only which are dressed, which bear, attain to it.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: High in the seat of heaven is spread the Scorcher's sieve: its threads are standing separate, glittering with light. The Swift Ones favour him who purifieth this: with consciousness they stand upon the height of heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The foremost spotted Steer hath made the Mornings shine, and yearning after strength sustains all things that be. By his high wisdom have the mighty Sages wrought: the Fathers who behold mankind laid down the germ,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Gandharva verily protects his dwellingplace; Wondrous, he guards the generations of the Gods. Lord of the snare, he takes the foeman with the snare: those who are most devout have gained a share of meath.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Rich in oblations! robed in cloud, thou corapassest oblation, sacrifice, the mighty seat of Gods. King, on thy chariot-sieve thou goest up to war, and with a thousand weapons winnest lofty fame. Next: HYMN LXXXIV. Soma Pavamana.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: FLOW, cheering Gods, most active, winner of the flood, for Indra, and for Vāyu, and for Varuṇa. Bestow on us to-day wide room with happiness, and in tbine ample dwelling laud the Host of Heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He who hath come anear to creatures that have life, Immortal Soma flows onward to all of them. Effecting, for our aid, both union and release, Indu, like Sūrya, follows closely after Dawn.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He who is poured with milk, he who within the plants hastes bringing treasure for the happiness of Gods, He, poured forth in a stream flows with the lightning's flash, Soma who gladdens Indra and the Host of Heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Winner of thousands, he, this Soma, flows along, raising a vigorous voice that wakens with the dawn. Indu with winds drives on the ocean of the air, he sinks within the jars, he rests in Indra's heart.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The kine with milk dress him who makes the milk increase, Soma, amid the songs, who finds the light of heaven. Winner of wealth, the effectual juice is flowing on, Singer and Sage by wisdom, dear as heaven itself. Next: HYMN LXXXV. Soma Pavamana.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: FLOW on to Indra, Soma, carefully effused: let sickness stay afar together with the fiends. Let not the double-tongued delight them with thy juice. here be thy flowing drops laden with opulence.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Pavamana, urge us forward in the fight thou art the vigour of the Gods, the well-loved drink. Smite thou our enemies who raise the shout of joy: Indra, drink Soma juice, and drive away our foes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Unharmed, best Cheerer, thou, O Indu, flowest on: thou, even thou thyself, art Indra's noblest food. Full many a wise man lifts to thee the song of praise, and hails thee with a kiss as Sovran of this world.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Wondrous, with hundred streams, hymned in a thousand songs, Indu pours out for Indra his delightrul meath. Winning us land and waters, flow thou hitherward: Rainer of bounties, Soma, make broad way for us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Roaring within the beaker thou art balmed with milk: thou passest through the fleecy filter all at once. Carefully cleansed and decked like a prizewinning steed, O Soma, thou hast flowed down within Indra's throat.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Flow onward sweet of flavour for the Heavenly Race, for Indra sweet, whose name is easily invoked: Flow sweet for Mitra, Varuṇa, and Vāyu, rich in meath, inviolable for Bṛhaspati.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ten rapid fingers deck the Courser in the jar: with hymns the holy singers send their voices forth. The filtering juices hasten to their eulogy, the drops that gladden find their way to Indra's heart.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: While thou art purified pour on us hero strength, great, far-extended shelter, spacious pasturage. Let no oppression master this our holy work: may we, O Indu, gain all opulence through thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Steer who sees afar hath risen above the sky: the Sage hath caused the lights of heaven to give their shine. The. King is passing through the filter with a roar: they drain the milk of heaven from him who looks on men.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: High in the vault of heaven, unceasing, honey-tongued, the Loving Ones drain out the mountain-haunting Steer,— The drop that hath grown great in waters, in the lake meath-rich, in the stream's wave and in the cleansing sieve.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Loving Ones besought with many voices the Eagle who had flown away to heaven. Hymns kiss the Youngling worthy of laudation, resting on earth, the Bird of golden colour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: High to heaven's vault hath the Gandharva risen, beholding all his varied forms and figures. His ray hath shone abroad with gleaming splendour: pure, he hath lighted both the worlds, the Parents. Next: HYMN LXXXVI. Soma Pavamana.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THY gladdening draughts, O Pavamana, urged by song flow swiftly of themselves like sons of fleet-foot mares. The drops of Soma juice, those eagles of the heavens, most cheering, rich in meath, rest in the reservoir.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As rapid chariot-steeds, so turned in several ways have thine exhilarating juices darted forth, Soma-drops rich in meath, waves, to the Thunder-armed, to Indra, like milch-kine who seek their calf with milk.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like a steed urged to battle, finder of the light; speed onward to the cloud-born reservoir of heaven, A Steer that o’er the woolly surface seeks the sieve, Soma while purified for Indra's nourishment.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Fleet as swift steeds, thy drops, divine, thought-swift, have been, O Pavamana, poured with milk into the vat. The Ṛṣis have poured in continuous Soma drops, ordainers who adorn thee, Friend whom Ṛṣis love.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O thou who seest all things, Sovran as thou art and passing strong, thy rays encompass all abodes. Pervading with thy natural powers thou flowest on, and as the whole world's Lord, O Soma, thou art King.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The beams of Pavamana, sent from earth and heaven, his ensigns who is ever steadfast, travel round. When on the sieve the Golden-hued is cleansed, he rests within the vats as one who seats him in his place.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Served with fair rites he flows, ensign of sacrifice: Soma advances to the special place of Gods. He speeds with thousand currents to the reservoir, and passes through the filter bellowing as a bull.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Sovran dips him in the seain and the streams, and set in rivers with the waters' wave moves on. High heaven's Sustainer at the central point of earth, raised on the fleecy surface Pavamana stands.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He on whose high decree the heavens and earth depend nath roared and thundered like the summit of the sky. Soma flows on obtaining Indra's friendly love, and, as they purify him, settles in the jars.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He, light of sacrifice distils delicious meath, most wealthy, Father and begetter of the Gods. He, gladdening, best of Cheerers, juice!hat Indra loves, enriches with mysterious treasure earth and heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The vigorous and far-seeing one, the Lord of heaven, flows, shouting to the beaker, with his thousand streams. Coloured like gold he rests in seats where Mitra dwells, the Steer made beautiful by rivers and by sheep.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In forefront of the rivers Pavamana speeds, in forefront of the hymn, foremost among the kine. He shares the mighty booty in the van of war: the well-armed Steer is purified by worshippers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This heedful Pavamana, like a bird sent forth, hath with his wave flowed onward to the fleecy sieve. O Indra, through thy wisdom, b thy thought, O Sage, Soma flows bright and pure between the earth and heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He, clad in mail that reaches heaven, the Holy One, filling the firmament stationed amid the worlds, Knowing. the realm of light, hath come to us in rain: he summons to himself his own primeval Sire.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He who was first of all to penetrate his form bestowed upon his race wide shelter and defence. From that high station which he hath in loftiest heaven he comes victorious to all encounters here.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indu hath started for Indra's special place and slights not as a Friend the promise of his Friend. Soma speeds onward like a youth to youtlitial maids, and gains the beaker by a course of bundred paths.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Your songs, exhilarating, tuneful, uttering praise, are come into the placns where the people meet. Worshippers have exalted Soma with their hymns, and milch kine have come near to meet him with their milk.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Soma, Indu, while they cleanse thee, pour on us accumulateds Plentiful, nutritious food, Which, ceaseless, thrice a day shall yield us hero power enriched with store of nourishment, and strength, and Meath.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Far-seeing Soma flows, the Steer, the Lord of hymns, the Furtherer of day, of morning, and of heaven. Mixt with the streams he caused the beakers to resound, and with the singers' aid they entered Indra's heart.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: On, with the prudent singers, flows the ancient Sage and guided by the men hath roared about the vats. Producing Trita's name, may he pour forth the meath, that Vāyu and that Indra may become his Friends.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He, being purified, hath made the Mornings shine: this, even this is he who gave the rivers room. He made the Three Times Seven pour out the milky flow: Soma, the Cheerer, yields whate’er the heart finds sweet.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Flow, onward, Soma, in thine own celestial forms, flow, Indu, poured within the beaker and the sieve. Sinking into the throat of Indra with a roar, led by the men thou madest Sūrya mount to heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Pressed out with stones thou flowest onward to the sieve, O Indu, entering the depths of Indra's throat. Far-sighted Soma, now thou lookest on mankind: thou didst unbar the cowstall for the Aṅgirases.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In thee, O Soma, while thou purifitedst thee, high-thoughted sages, seeking favour, have rejoiced. Down from the heavens the Falcon brought thee hitherward, even thee, O Indu, thee whom all our hymns adorn.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Seven Milch-kine glorify the Tawny-coloured One while with his wave in wool he purifies himself. The living men, the mighty, have impelled the Sage into the waters' lap, the place of sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indu, attaining purity, plunges through the foe, making Ilis ways all easy for the pious man. Making the kine his mantle, he, the lovely Sage, runs like a sporting courser onward through the fleece.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The ceaseless watery fountains with their hundred streams sing, as they hasten near, to him the Golden-hued Him, clad in robes of milk, swift fingers beautify on the third height and in the luminous realm of heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These are thy generations of celestial seed thou art the Sovran Lord of all the world of life. This universe, O Pavamana, owns thy sway; thou, Indu, art the first establisher of Law.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou art the sea, O Sage who bringest alf to light: under thy Law are these five regions of the world. Tlou reachest out beyond the earth, beyond the heavens: thine are the lights, O Pavamana, thine the Sun.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou in the filter, Soma Pavamana, art purified to support the region for the Gods. The chief, the longing ones have sought to hold thee fast, and all these living creatures have been turned to thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Onward the Singer travels o’er the fleecy sieve. the Tawny Steer hath bellowed in the wooden vats. Hymns have been sung aloud in resonant harmony, and holy songs kiss him, the Child who claims our praise.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He hath assumed the rays of Sūrya for his robe, spinning, as he knows bow, the triply-twisted thread. He, guiding to the newest rules of Holy Law, comes as the Women's Consort to the special place.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: On flows the King of rivers and the Lord of heaven: he follows with a shout the paths of Holy Law. The Golden-hued is poured forth, with his hundred streams, Wealth-bringer, lifting up his voice while purified.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Fain to be cleansed, thou, Pavamana, pourest out, like wondrous Sūrya, through the fleece, an ample sea. Purified with the hands, pressed by the men with stones, thou speedest on to mighty booty-bringing war.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, Pavamana, sendest food and power in streams. thou sittest in the beakers as a hawk on trees, For Indra poured as cheering juice to make him glad, as nearest and farseeing bearer-up of heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Sisters Seven, the Mothers, stand around the Babe, the noble, new-born Infant, skilled in holy song, Gandharva of the floods, divine, beholding men, Soma, that he may reign as King of all the world.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As Sovran Lord thereof thou Passest through these worlds, O Indu, harnessing thy tawny well-winged Mares. May they pour forth for thee milk and oil rich in sweets: O Soma, let the folk abide in thy decree.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Soma, thou beholdest men from every side: O Pavamana, Steer, thou wanderest through these. Pour out upon us wealth in treasure and in gold: may we have strength to live among the things that be.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Winner of gold and goods and cattle flow thou on, set as impregner, Indu, mid the worlds of life. Rich in brave men art thou, Soma, who winnest all: these holy singers wait upon thee with the song.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The wave of flowing meath hath wakened up desires: the Steer enrobed in milk plunges into the streams. Borne on his chariot-sieve the King hath risen to war, and with a thousand rays hath won him high renown.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Dear to all life, he sends triumphant praises forth, abundant, bringing offspring, each succeeding day. From Indra crave for us, Indu, when thou art quaffed, the blessing that gives children, wealth that harbours steeds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When days begin, the strong juice, lovely, golden-hued, is recognized by wisdom more and more each day, He, stirring both the Races, goes between the two, the bearer of the word of men and word of Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They balm him, balm him over balm him thoroughly, caress the mighty strength and balm it with the meath. They seize the flying Steer at the stream's breathing-place: cleansing with gold they grasp the Animal herein.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sing forth to Pavamana skilled in holy song: the juice is flowing onward like a mighty stream. He.glideth like a serpent from his ancient skin, and like a playful horse the Tawny Steer hath run.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Dweller in floods, King, foremost, he displays his might, set among living things as measurer of days. Distilling oil he flows, fair, billowy, golden-hued, borne on a car of light, sharing one hom-e with wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Loosed is the heavens! support, the uplifted cheering juice: the triply-mingled draught flows round into the worlds. The holy hymns caress the stalk that claims our praise, when singers have approached his beauteous robe with song.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thy strearns that flow forth rapidly collected run over the fine fleece of the sheep as thou art cleansed. When, Indu, thou art. balmed with milk within the bowl, thou sinkest in the jars, O Soma, when expressed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Winner of power, flow, Soma, worthy of our laud: run onward to the fleece as well-beloved meath. Destroy, O Indu, all voracious Rākṣasas. With brave sons in the assembly let our speech be bold. Next: HYMN LXXXVII. Soma Pavamana.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: RUN onward to the reservoir and seat thee: cleansed by the men speed forward to the battle. Making thee beauteous like an able courser, forth to the sacred grass with reins they lead thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indu, the well-armed God, is flowing onward, who quells the curse and guards from treacherous onslaught, Father, begetter of the Gods, most skilful, the buttress of the heavens and earth's supporter.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Ṛṣi and Sage, the Champion of the people, cleft and sagacious, Uśanā in wisdom, He hath discovered even their hidden nature, the Cows' concealed and most mysterious title.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This thine own Soma rich in meath, O Indra, Steer for the Steer, hath flowed into the filter. The strong Free-giver, winning hundreds, thousands, hath reached the holy grass that never fails him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These Somas are for wealth of countless cattle, renown therefor, and mighty strength immortal. These have been sent forth, urified by strainers, like steeds who rusg to battle fain for glory.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He, while he cleanses him, invoked of many, hath flowed to give the people all enjoyment. Thou whom the Falcon brought, bring, dainty viands, bestir thyself and send us wealth and booty.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This Soma, pressed into the cleansing filter, hath run as ’twere a host let loose, the Courser; Like a strong bull who whets his horns kpen-pointed, like a brave warrior in the fray for cattle.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He issued forth from out the loftiest mountain, and found kine hidden somewhere in a stable. Soma's stream clears itself for thee, O Indra, like lightning thundering through the clouds of heaven,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Cleansing thyselr, and borne along with Indra, Soma, thou goest round the herd of cattle. May thy praise help us, Mighty One, prompt Giver, to the full ample food which thou bestowest. Next: HYMN LXXXVIII. Soma Pavamana.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: FOR thee this Soma is effused, O Indra: drink of this juice; for thee the stream is flowing- Soma, which thou thyself hast made and chosen, even Indu, for thy special drink to cheer thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like a capacious car hath it been harnessed, the Mighty; to acquire abundant treasures. Then in the sacrifice they celebrated all triumphs won by Nahus -n the battle.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like Vāyu with his team, moving at pleasure, most gracious when invoked like both Nāsatyas, Thou art thyself like the Wealth-Giver, Soma! who grants all boons, like song-inspiring Pūṣan.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like Indra who hath done great deeds, thou, Soma, art slayer of the Vṛtras, Fort-destroyer. Like Pedu's horse who killed the brood of serpents, thus thou, O Soma, slayest every Dasyu.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like Agni loosed amid the forest, fiercely he winneth splendour in the running waters. Like one who fights, the roaring of the mighty, thus Soma Pavamana sends his current.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These Somas passing through the fleecy filter, like rain descending from the clouds of heaven, Have been effused and poured into the beakers, swiftly like rivers running lowly seaward.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Flow onward like the potent band of Maruts, like that Celestial Host whom none revileth. Quickly be gracious unto us like waters, like sacrifice victorious, thousand-fashioned.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thine are King Varuṇa's eternal statutes, lofty and deep, O Soma, is thy glory. All-pure art thou like Mitra the beloved, adorable, like Aryaman, O Soma. Next: HYMN LXXXIX. Soma Pavamana.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THIS Chariot-horse hath moved along the pathways, and Pavamana flowed like rain from heaven. With us hath Soma with a thousand currents sunk in the wood, upon his Mother's bosom.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: King, he hath clothed him in the robe of rivers, mounted the straightest-going ship of Order. Sped by the Hawk the drop hath waxed in waters: the father drains it, drains the Father's offspring.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They come to him, red, tawny, Lord of Heaven, the watchful Guardian of the meath, the Lion. First, Hero in the fight, he seeks the cattle, and with his eye the Steer is our protector.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They harness to the broad-wheeled car the mighty Courser whose back bears meath, unwearied, awful. The twins, the sisters brighten him, and strengthen-these children of one damethe vigorous Racer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Four pouring out the holy oil attend him, sitting together in the same container. To him they flow, when purified, with homage, and still, from every side, are first about him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He is the buttress of the heavens, supporter of earth, and in his hand are all the people. Be the team's Lord a well to thee the singer: cleansed is the sweet plant's stalk for deed of glory.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Fighting, uninjured come where Gods are feasted; Soma, as Vitra-slayer flow for Indra. Vouchsafe us ample riches very splendid may we be masters of heroic vigour. Next: HYMN XC. Soma Pavamana,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: URGED On, the Father of the Earth and Heaven hath gone forth like a car to gather booty, Going to Indra, sharpening his weapons, and in his hand containing every treasure.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To him the tones of sacred song have sounded, Steer of the triple height, the Life-bestower. Dwelling in wood as Varuṇa in rivers, lavishing treasure he distributes blessings

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Great Conqueror, warnor-girt, Lord of all heroes, flow on thy way as he who winneth riches; With sharpened. arms, with swift bow, never vanquished in battle, vanquishing in fight the foemen.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Giving security, Lord of wide dominion, send us both earth and heaven with all their fulness. Striving to win the Dawns, the light, the waters, and cattle, call to us abundant vigour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Soma, gladden Varuṇa and Mitra; cheer, Indu Pavamana! Indra, Viṣṇu. Cheer thou the Gods, the Company of Maruts: Indu, cheer mighty Indra to rejoicing.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thus like a wise and potent King flow onward, destroying with thy vigour all misfortunes. For our well-spoken hymn give life, O Indu. Do ye preserve us evermore with blessings. Next: HYMN XCI. Soma Pavamana.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As for a chariot-race, the skilful Speaker, Chief, Sage, Inventor, hath, with song, been started. The sisters ten upon the fleecy summit drive on the Car-horse to the resting places.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The drop of Soma, pressed by wise Nahusyas, becomes the banquet of the Heavenly People- Indu, by hands of mortal men made beauteous, immortal, with the sheep and cows and waters.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Steer roaring unto Steer, this Pavamana, this juice runs to the white milk of the milch-cow. Through thousand fine hairs goes the tuneful Singer, like Sūra by his fair and open pathways.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Break down the, strong seats even of the demons: cleansing thee, Indu, robd thyself in vigour. Rend with thy swift bolt, coming from above them, those who are near and those who yet are distant.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Prepare the forward paths in ancient manner for the new bymn, thou Giver of all bounties. Those which are high and hard for foes to conquer may we gain from thee, Active! Food-bestower!

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So purifying thee vouchsafe us waters, heaven's light, and cows, offipring and many children. Give us health, ample land, and lights, O Soma, and grant us long to look upon the sunshine. Next: HYMN XCII. Soma Pavamana.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THE gold-hued juice, poured out upon the filter, is started like a car sent forth to conquer. He hath gained song and vigour while they cleansed him, and hath rejoiced the Gods with entertainments.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He who beholdeth man hath reached the filter: bearing his name, the Sage hath sought his dwelling. The Ṛṣis came to him, seven holy singers, when in the bowls he settled as Invoker.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Shared by all Gods, mobt wise, propitious, Soma goes, while they cleanse him, to his constant station. Let him rejoice in all his lofty wisdom to the Five Tribes the Sage attains with labour.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In thy mysterious place, O Pavamana Soma, are all the Gods, the Thrice-Eleven. Ten on the fleecy height, themselves, self-prompted, and seven fresh rivers, brighten and adorn thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now let this be the truth of Pavamana, there where all singers gather them together, That he hath given us room and made the daylight, hath holpen Manu and repelled the Dasyu.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As the priest seeks the station rich in cattle, like a true King who goes to great assemblies, Soma hath sought the beakers while they cleansed him, and like a wild bull, in the wood hath settled. Next: HYMN XCIII. Soma Pavamana.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: TEN sisters, pouring out the rain together, swift-moving thinkers of the sage, adorn him. Hither hath run the gold-hued Child of Sūrya and reached the vat like a fleet vigorous courser.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Even as a youngling crying to his mothers, the bounteous Steer hath flowed along to waters. As youth to damsel, so with milk he hastens on to the. chose meeting-place, the beaker.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Yea, swollen is the udder of the milch-cow: thither in streams goes very sapient Indu. The kine make ready, as with new-washed treasures, the Head and Chief with milk within the vessels.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With all the Gods, O Indu Pavamana, while thou art roaring send us wealth in horses. Hither upon her car come willing Plenty, inclined to us, to give us of her treasures.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now unto us mete riches, while they cleansethee, all-glorious, swelling wealth, with store of heroes. Long be his life who worships, thee, O Indu. May he, enriched with prayer, come soon and early. Next: HYMN XCIV. Soma Pavamana.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WHEN beauties strive for him as for a charger, then strive the songs like soldiers for the sunlight. Acting the Sage, he flows enrobed in waters and song as ’twere a stall that kine may prosper.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The worlds expand to hirn who from aforetime found light to spread the law of life eternal. The swelling songs, like kine within the stable, in deep devotion call aloud on Indu.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: When the sage bears his holy wisdom round him, like a car visiting all worlds, the Hero, Becoming fame, mid Gods, unto the mortal, wealth to the skilled, worth praise mid the Ever-present,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For glory born be hath come forth to glory: he giveth life and glory to the singers. They, clothed in glory, have become immortal. He, measured in his course, makes frays successful.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Stream to us food and vigour, kine and horses: give us broad lights and fill thGods with rapture. All ther are easy things for thee to master thou, Pavamana Soma, quellest foemen. Next: HYMN XCV Soma Pavamana.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Loud neighs the Tawny Steed when started, settling deep in the wooden vessel while they cleanse him. Led by the men he takes the milk for raiment: then shall he, through his powers, engender praise-songs.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As one who rows drives on his boat, he, Gold-hued, sends forth his voice, loosed on the path of Order. As God, the secret names of Gods he utters, to be declared on sacred grass more widely.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hastening onward like the waves of waters, our holy hymns are pressing nigh to Soma. To him they come with lowly adoration, and, longing, enter him who longs to meet them.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They drain the stalk, the Steer who dwells on mountains, even as a Bull who decks him on the upland. Hymns follow and attend him as he bellows: Trita bears Varuṇa aloft in ocean.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sending thy voice out as Director, loosen the Invoker's thought, O Indu, as they cleanse thee. While thou and Indra rule for our advantage, may we be masters of heroic vigour. Next: HYMN XCVI. Soma Pavamana

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: IN forefront of the cars forth goes the Hero, the Leader, winning spoil: his host rejoices. Soma endues his robes of lasting colours, and blesses, for his friends, their calls on Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Men decked with gold adorn his golden tendril, incessantly with steed-impelling homage. The Friend of Indra mounts his car well-knowing, he comes thereon to meet the prayer we offer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O God, for service of the Gods flow onward, for food sublime, as Indra's drink, O Soma. Making the floods, bedewing earth and heaven, come from the vast, comfort us while we cleanse thee

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Flow for prosperity and constant Vigour, flow on for happiness and high perfection. This is the wish of these friends assembled: this is my wish, O Soma Pavamana.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Father of holy hymns, Soma flows onward the Father of the earth, Father of heaven: Father of Agni, Sūrya's generator, the Father who begat Indra and Viṣṇu.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Brahman of Gods, the Leader of the poets, Ṛṣi of sages, Bull of savage creatures, Falcon amid the vultures, Axe of forests, over the cleansing sieve goes Soma singing.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He, Soma Pavamana, like a river, hath stirred the wave of voice, our songs and praises. Beholding these inferior powers in cattle, he rests among them as a Steer well-knowing.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As Gladdener, Warrior never harmed in battle, with thousand genial streams, pour strength and vigour. As thoughtful Pavamana, urge O Indu, speeding the kine, the plant's wave on to Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Dear, grateful to the Gods, on to the beaker moves Soma, sweet to Indra, to delight him. With hundred powers, with thousand currents, Indu, like a strong car-horse, goes to the assembly.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Born in old time as finder-out of treasures, drained with the stone, decking himself in waters, Warding off curses, King of all existence, he shall find way for prayer the while they cleanse him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For our sage fathers, Soma Pavamana, of old performed, by thee, their sacred duties. Fighting unvanquished, open the enclosures: enrich us with large gifts of steeds and heroes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As thou didst flow for Manu Life-bestowing, Foe-queller, Comforter, rich in oblations, Even thus flow onward now conferring riches: combine with Indra, and bring forth thy weapons.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Flow onward, Soma, rich in sweets and holy,. enrobed in waters on the fleecy summit. Settle in vessels that are full of fatness, as cheering and most gladdening drink for Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Pour, hundred-streamed, winner of thousands, mighty at the Gods’ banquet, Pour the rain of heaven, While thou with rivers roarest in the beaker, and blent with milk prolongest our existence.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Purified with our holy hymns, this Soma o’ertakes malignities like some strong charger, Like fresh milk poured by Aditi, like passage in ample room, or like a docile car-horse.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Cleansed by the pressers, armed with noble weapons, stream to us the fair secret name thou bearest. Pour booty, like a horse, for love of glory God, Soma, send us kine, and send us Vāyu.
