translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They deck him at his birth, the lovely Infant, the Maruts with their troop adorn the Car-horse. By songs a Poet and a Sage by wisdom, Soma joes singing through the cleansing filter.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Light-winner, Ṛṣi-mindcd, Ṛṣi-maker, hymned in a thousand hymns, Leader of sages, A Steer who strives to gain his third form, Soma is, like Virāj, resplendent as a Singer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hawk seated in the bowls, Bird wide-extended, the Banner seeking kine and wielding weapons, Following close the sea, the wave of waters, the great Bull tells his fourth form and declares it.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like a fair youth who decorates his body, a courser rushing to the gain of riches, A steer to herds, so, flowing to the pitcher, he with a roar hath passed into the beakers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Flow on with might as Pavamana, Indu flow loudly roaring through the fleecy filter. Enter the beakers sporting, as they cleanse thee, and let thy gladdening juice make Indra joyful.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: His streams have been effused in all their fulness, and he hath entered, balmed with milk, the goblets. Singing his psalm, well-skilled in song, a Chanter, be comes as ’twere to his friend's sister roaring.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Chasing our foes thou comest, Pavamana Indu, besting, as lover to his darling. As a bird flies and settles in the forest, thus Soma settles, purified, in goblets.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With full stream and abundant milk, O Soma, thy beams come, like a woman, as they cleanse thee. He, gold-hued, rich in boons, brought to the waters, hath roared within the goblet of the pious. Next: HYMN XCVII. Soma Pavamana

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: MADE pure by this man's urgent zeal and impulse the God hath to the Gods his juice imparted. He goes, effused and singing, to the filter, like priest to measured seats supplied with cattle.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Robed in fair raiment meet to wear in battle, a mighty Sage pronouncing invocations. Roll onward to the beakers as they cleanse thee, far-seeing at the feast of Gods, and watchful.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Dear, he is brightened on the fleecy summit, a Prince among us, nobler than the noble. Roar out as thou art purified, run forward. Do ye preserve us evermore with blessings.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let us sing praises to the Gods: sing loudly, send ye the Soma forth for mighty riches. Let him flow, sweetly-flavoured, through the filter, and let our pious one rest in the pitcher.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Winning the friendship of the Deities, Indu flows in a thousand streams to make them joyful. Praised by the men after the ancient statute, he hath come nigh, for our great bliss, to Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Flow, Gold-hued, cleansing thee, to enrich the singer: let thy juice go to Indra to support him. Come nigh, together with the Gods, for bounty. Do ye preserve us evermore with blessings.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The God declares the Deities' generations, like Uśanā, proclaiming lofty wisdom. With brilliant kin, far-ruling, sanctifying, the Boar advances, singing, to the places.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Swans, the Vrsaganas from anear us have brought their restless spirit to our dwelling. Friends come to Pavamana meet for praises, and sound in concert their resistless music.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He follows the Wide-strider's rapid movement: cows low, as ’twere, to him who sports at pleasure. He with the sharpened horns brings forth abundance: the Silvery shines by night, by day the Golden.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Strong Indu, bathed in milk, flows on for Indra, Soma exciting strength, to make him joyful. He quells malignities and slays the demons, the King of mighty power who brings us comfort.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Then in a stream he flows, milked out with press-stones, mingled with sweetness, through the fleecy filter- Indu rejoicing in the love of Indra, the God who gladdens, for the God's enjoyment.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As he is purified he pours out treasures, a God bedewing Gods with his own juices. Indu hath, wearing qualities by seasons, on the raised fleece engaged, the ten swift fingers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Red Bull bellowing to the kine advances, causing the heavens and earth to roar and tbunder. Well is he beard like Indra's shout in battle: letting this voice be known he hastens hither.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Swelling with milk, abounding in sweet flavours, urging the meath-rich plant thou goest onward. Raising a shout thou flowest as they cleanse thee, when thou, O Soma, art effused for Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So flow thou on inspiriting, for rapture, aiming deatb-shafts at him who stays the waters, Flow to us wearing thy resplendent colour, effused and eager for the kine, O Soma.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Pleased with us, Indu, send us as thou flowest good easy paths in ample space and comforts. Dispelling, as ’twere with a club, misfortunes, run o’er the height, run o’er the fleecy summit.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Pour on us rain celestial, quickly streaming, refreshing, fraught with health and ready bounty. Flow, Indu, send these Winds thy lower kinsmen, setting them free like locks of hair unbraided.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Part, like a knotted tangle, while they cleanse thee, O Soma, righteous and unrighteous conduct. Neigh like a tawny courser who is loosened, come like a youth, O God, a house-possessor.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For the God's service, for delight, O Indu, run o’er the height, run o'ver the fleecy summit. With thousand streams, inviolate, sweet-scented, flow on for gain of strength that conquers heroes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Without a car, without a rein to guide them, unyoked, like coursers started in the contest, These brilliant drops of Soma juice run forward. Do ye, O Deities, come nigh to drink them.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So for our banquet of the Gods, O Indu, pour down the rain of heaven into the vessels. May Soma grant us riches sought with longing, mighty, exceeding strong, with store of heroes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: What time the loving spirit's word had formed him Chief of all food, by statute of the Highest, Then loudly lowing came the cows to Indu, the chosen, well-loved Master in the beaker.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Sage, Celestial, liberal, raining bounties, pours as he flows the Genuine for the Truthful. The King shall be effectual strength's upholder: he by the ten bright reins is mostly guided.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He who beholds mankind, made pure with filters, the King supreme of Deities and mortals, From days of old is Treasure-Lord of riches: he, Indu, cherishes fair well-kept Order.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Haste, like a steed, to vittory for glory, to Indra's and to Vāyu's entertainment. Give us food ample, thousandfold: be, Soma, the finder-out of riches when they cleanse thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Effused by us let God-delighting Somas bring as they flow a home with noble heroes. Rich in all boons like priests acquiring favour, the worshippers of heaven, the best of Cheerers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So, God, for service of the Gods flow onward, flow, drink of Gods, for ample food, O Soma. For we go forth to war against the mighty make heaven and earth well stablished by thy cleansing.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, yoked by strong men, neighest like a courser, swifter than thought is, like an awful lion. By paths directed hitherward, the straightest, send thou us happiness, Indu, while they cleanse thee.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Sprung from the Gods, a hundred streams, a thousand, have been effused: sages prepare and purge them. Bring us from heaven the means of winnning, Indu; thou art-forerunnner of abundant riches.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The streams of days, were poured as ’twere from heaven: the wise King doth not treat his friend unkindly. Like a son following his father's wishes, grant to this family success and safety.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now are thy streams poured forth with all their sweetness, when, purified. thou goest through the filter. The race of kine is thy gift, Pavarridna: when born thou madest Sūrya rich with brightness.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bright, bellowing aiong the path of Order, thou shinest as the form of life eternal. Thou flowest on as gladdening drink for Indra, sending thy voice out with the hymns of sages.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Pouring out streams at the Gods’ feast with service, thou, Soma, lookest down, a heavenly Eagle. Enter the Soma-holding beaker, Indu, and with a roar approach the ray of Sarya.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Three are the voices that the Courser utters: he speaks the thought of prayer, the law of Order. To the Cow's Master come the Cows inquiring: the hymns with eager longing come to Soma.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To Soma come the Cows, the Milch-kine longing, to Soma sages with their hvmns inquiring. Soma, effused, is purified and blended our hymns and Tṛṣṭup songs unite in Soma.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thus, Soma, as we pour thee into vessels, while thou art purified flow for our welfare. Pass into Indra with a mighty roaring make the voice swell, and generate abundance.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Singer of true songs, ever-watchful, Soma hath settled in the ladles when they cleanse him. Him the Adhvaryus, paired and eager, follow, leaders of sacrifice and skilful-handed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Cleansed near the Sun as ’twere he as Creator hath filled full heaven and earth, and hath disclosed them. He by whose dear help men gain all their wishes shall yield the precious meed as to a victor.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He, being cleansed, the Strengthener and Increaser, Soma the Bounteous, helped us with his lustre, Wherewith our sires of old who knew the footsteps found light and stole the cattle from the mountain.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In the first vault of heaven loud roared the Ocean, King of all being, generating creatures. Steer, in the filter, on the fleecy summit, Soma, the Drop effused, hath waxen mighty.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Soma the Steer, in that as Child of Waters he chose the Gods, performed that great achievement. He, Pavamana, granted strength to Indra; he, Indu, generated light in Sūrya.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Make Vāyu glad,, for furtherance and bounty: cheer Varuṇa and Mitra, as they cleanse thee. Gladden the Gods, gladden the host of Maruts: make Heaven and Earth rejoice, O God, O Soma.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Flow onward righteous slayer of the wicked, driving away our enemies and sickness, Blending thy milk with milk which cows afford us. We are thy friends, thou art the Friend of Indra.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Pour us a fount of meath, a spring of treasure; send us a hero son and happy fortune. Be sweet to India when they cleanse thee, Indu, and pour down riches on us from the ocean.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Strong Soma, pressed, like an impetuous courser, hath flowed in stream as a flood speeding downward. Cleansed, he hath settled in his wooden dwelling: Indu hath flowed with milk and with the waters.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Strong, wise, for thee who longest for his coming this Soma here flows to the bowls, O Indra. He, chariot-borne, sun-bright, and truly potent, was poured forth like the longing of the pious.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He, purified with ancient vital vigour, pervading all his Daughter's forms and figures, Finding his threefold refuge in the waters, goes singing, as a priest, to the assemblies.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now, chariot-borne, flow unto us, God Soma, as thou art purified flow to the saucers, Sweetest in waters, rich in meath, and holy, as Savitar the God is, truthfulminded.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To feast him, flow mid song and hymn, to Vāyu, flow purified to Varuṇa and Mitra. Flow to the song-inspiring car-borne Hero, to mighty Indra, him who wields the thunder.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Pour on us garments that shall clothe us meetly, send, purified, miIch-kine, abundant yielders. God Soma, send us chariot-drawing horses that they may bring us treasures bright and golden.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Send to us in a stream celestial riches, send us, when thou art cleansed, what earth containeth, So that thereby we may acquire possessions and Rsihood in Jamadagni's manner.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Pour forth this wealth with this purification: flow onward to the yellow lake, O Indu. Here, too, the Ruddy, wind-swift, full of wisdom, Shall give a son to him who cometh quickly.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Flow on for us with this purification to the famed ford of thee whose due is glory. May the Foe-queller shake us down, for triumph, like a tree's ripe fruit, sixty thousand treasures.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Eagerly do we pray for those two exploits, at the blue lake and Prsana, wrought in battle. He sent our enemies to sleep and slew thern, and turned away the foolish and unfriendly.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou comest unto three extended filters, and hasteriest through each one as they cleanse thee. Thou art the giver of the gift, a Bhaga, a Maghavan for liberal lords, O Indu.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: This Soma here, the Wise, the All-obtainer, flows on his way as King of all existence. Driving the drops at our assemblies, Indu completely traverses the fleecy filter.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Great Inviolate are kissing Indu, and singing in his place like eager sages. The wise men send him forth with ten swift fingers, and balm his form with essence of the waters.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Soma, may we, with thee as Pavamana, pile up together all our spoil in battle. This boon vouchsafe us Varuṇa and Mitra, and Aditi and Sindhu, Earth and Heaven. Next: HYMN XCVIII. Soma Pavamana

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: STREAM on us riches that are sought by many, best at winning strength Riches, O Indu, thousandfold, glorious, conquering the great.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Effused, he hath, as on a car, invested him in fleecy mail: Onward hath Indu flowed in streams, impelled, surrounded by the wood.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Effused, this Indu hath flowed on, distilling rapture, to the fleece: He goes erect, as seeking kine in stream, with light, to sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For thou thyself, O Indu, God, to every mortal worshipper Attractest riches thousandfold, made manifest in hundred forms.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Good Vṛtra-slayer, may we be still nearest to this wealth of thine Which many crave, nearest to food and happiness, Resistless One!

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Whom, bright with native splendour, crushed between the pair of pressingstones- The wavy Friend whom Indra loves-the twice-five sisters dip and bathe,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Him with the fleece they purify, brown, golden-hued, beloved of all, Who with exhilarating juice goes forth to all the Deities.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Through longing for this sap of yours ye drink what brings ability, Even him who, dear as heaven's own light, gives to our princes high renown.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indu at holy rites produced you, Heaven and Earth, the Friends of men, Hill-haunting God the Goddesses. They bruised him where the roar was loud.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For Vṛtra-slaying Indra, thou, Soma, art poured that he may drink, Poured for the guerdon-giving man, poured for the God who sitteth there.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: These ancient Somas, at the break of day, have flowed into the sieve, Snorting away at early morn these foolish evil-hearted ones.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Friends, may the princes, ye and we, obtain this Most Resplendent One. Gain him who hath the smell of strength, win him whose home is very strength. Next: HYMN XCIX. Soma Pavamana.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THEY for the Bold and Lovely One ply manly vigour like a bow: joyous, in front of songs they weave bright raiment for the Lord Divine.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: And he, made beautiful by night, dips forward into strengthening food', What time the sacrificer's thoughts speed on his way the Golden-hued.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: We cleanse this gladdening drink of his the juice which Indra chiefly drinks—- That which kine took into their mouths, of old, and princes take it now.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To him, while purifying, they have raised the ancient psalm of praise: And sacred songs which bear the names of Gods have supplicated him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They purify him as he drops, courageous, in the fleecy sieve. Him they instruct as messenger to bear the sage's morning prayer.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Soma, best Cheerer, takes his seat, the while they cleanse him in the bowls. He as it were impregns the cow, and babbles on, the Lord of Song.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He is effused and beautified, a God for Gods, by skilful men. He penetrates the mighty floods collecting all he knows therein.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Pressed, Indu, guided by the men, thou art led to the cleaning sieve. Thou, yielding Indra highest joy, takest thy seat within the bowls. Next: HYMN C. Soma Pavamana.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THE Guileless Ones are singing praise to Indra's well beloved Friend, As, in the morning of its life, the mothers lick the new-born calf.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indu, while they cleanse thee bring, O Soma, doubly-waxing wealth Thou in the worshipper's abode causest all treasures to increase.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Set free the. song which mind hath yoked, even as thunder frees the rain: All treasures of the earth and heaven, O Soma, thou dost multiply.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thy stream when thou art pressed runs on like some victorious warrior's steed Hastening onward through the fleece like a fierce horse who wins the prize.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Flow on, Sage Soma, with thy stream to give us mental power and strength, Effused for Indra, for his drink, for Mitra and for Varuṇa.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Flow to the filter with thy stream, effused, best winner, thou, of spoil, O Soma, as most rich in sweets for Indra, Viṣṇu, and the Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The mothers, void of guiles, caress thee Golden-coloured, in the sieve, As cows, O Pavamana, lick the new-born calf, as Law commands.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, Pavamana, movest on with wondrous rays to great renown. Striving within the votary's house thou drivest all the glooms away.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Lord of great sway, thou liftest thee above the heavens, above the earth. Thou, Pavamana hast assumed thy coat of mail in majesty. Next: HYMN CI. Soma Pavamana

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: FOR first possession of your juice, for the exhilarating drink, Drive ye away the dog, my friends, drive ye the long-tongued dog away.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He who with purifying stream, effused, comes flowing hitherward, Indu, is like an able steed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The men with all-pervading song send unassailable Soma forth, By pressing-stones, to sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Somas, very rich in sweets, for which the sieve is destined, flow, Effused, the source of Indra's joy: may your strong juices reach the Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indu flows on for Indra's sake: thus have the Deities declared. The Lord of Speech exerts himself, Ruler of all, because of might.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Inciter of the voice of song, with thousand streams the ocean flows, Even Soma, Lord of opulence, the Friend of Indra, day by day.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As Pūṣan, Fortune, Bhaga, comes this Soma while they make him pure. He, Lord of the multitude, hath looked upon the earth and heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The dear cows lowed in joyful mood together to the gladdening drink. The drops as they were purified, the Soma juices, made then paths.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Pavamana, bring the juice, the mightiest, worthy to be famed, Which the Five Tribes have over them, whereby we may win opulence.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For us the Soma juices flow, the drops best furtherers of our weal, Effused as friends without a spot, benevolent, finders of the light.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Effused by means of pressing-stones, upon the ox-hide visible, They, treasure-finders, have announced food unto us from every side.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Tlese Soma juices, skilled in song, purified, blent with milk and curd, When moving and when firmly laid in oil, resemble lovely Suns.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let not the power of men restrain the voice of the outpouring juice: As Bhṛgu's sons chased Makha, so drive ye the greedy hound away.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Friend hath wrapped him in his robe, as in his parents arms, a son. He went, as lover to a dame, to take his station suitor-like.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: That Hero who produces strength, he who hath propped both worlds apart, Gold-hued, hath wrapped him in the sieve, to settle, priest-like, in his place.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Soma upon the ox's skin through the sheep's wool flows purified. Bellowing out, the Tawny Steer goes on to Indra's special place. Next: HYMN CIL Soma Pavamana.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THE Child, when blended with the streams, speeding the plan of sacrifice, Surpasses all things that are dear, yea, from of old.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The place, near the two pressing-stones of Trita, hath he occupied, Secret and dear through seven lights of sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Urge to three courses, on the heights of Trita, riches in a stream. He who is passing wise measures his courses out.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Even at his birth the Mothers Seven taught him, for glory, like a sage, So that he, firm and sure, hath set his mind on wealth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Under his sway, of one accord, are all the guileless Deities: Warriors to be envied, they, when they are pleased.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Babe whom they who strengthen Law have generated fair to see, Much longed for at the sacrifice, most liberal Sage,—

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To him, united, of themselves, come the young Parents of the rite, When they adorn him, duly weaving sacrifice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With wisdom and with radiant eyes unbar to us the stall of heaven, Speeding at solemn rite the plan of Holy Law. Next: HYMN CIII. Soma Pavamana.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To Soma who is purified as ordering Priest the song is raised: Bring meed, as ’twere, to one who makes thee glad with hymns.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Blended with milk and curds he flows on through the long wool of the sheep. The Gold-hued, purified, makes him three seats for rest.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: On through the long wool of the sheep to the meath-dropping vat he flows: The Ṛṣis’ sevenfold quire hath sung aloud to him.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Shared by all Gods, Infallible, the Leader of our holy hymns, Golden-hued Soma, being cleansed, hath reached the bowls.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: After thy Godlike qualities, associate with Indra, go, As a Priest purified by priests, Immortal One.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like a car-horse who shows his strength, a God effused for Deities. The penetrating Pavamana flows along. Next: HYMN CIV. Soma Pavamana.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: SIT down, O friends, and sing aloud to him who purifies himself: Deck him for glory, like a child, with holy rites.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Unite him bringing household wealth, even as a calf, with mother kine, Him who hath double strength, the God, delighting juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Purify him who gives us power, that he, most Blessed One, may be A banquet for the Troop, Mitra, and Varuṇa.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Voices have sung aloud to thee as finderout of wealth for us: We clothe the hue thou wearest with a robe of milk.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, Indu, art the food of Gods, O Sovran of all gladdening drinks: As Friend for friend, be thou best finder of success.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Drive utterly away from us each demon, each voracious fiend, The godless and the false: keep sorrow far away. Next: HYMN CV. Soma Pavamana

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: SING; ye aloud, O friends, to him who makes him pure for gladdening drink: They shall make sweet the Child with sacrifice and laud.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like as a calf with mother cows, so Indu is urged forth and sent, Glorified by our hymns, the God-delighting juice.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Effectual means of power is he, he is a banquet for the Troop, He who hath been effused, most rich in meath, for Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Flow to us, Indu, passing, strong, effused, with wealth of kine and steeds: I will spread forth above the milk thy radiant hue.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Lord of the tawny, Indu thou who art the God's most special food, As Friend to friend, for splendour be thou good to men.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Drive utterly, far away from us each godless, each voracious foe. O Indu, overcome and drive the false afar. Next: HYMN CVI. Soma Pavamana.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: To Indra, to the Mighty Steer, may these gold-coloured juices go, Drops rapidly produced, that find the light of heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Effused, this juice victorious flows for Indra, for his maintenance. Soma bethinks him of the Conqueror, as he knows.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May Indra in his raptures gain from him the grasp that gathers spoil, And, winning waters, wield the steerstrong thunderbolt.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Flow vigilant for Indra, thou Soma, yea, Indu, run thou on: Bring hither splendid strength that finds the light of heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Do thou, all-beautiful, purify for Indra's sake the mighty juice, Path-maker thou, far seeing, with a thousand ways.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Best finder of prosperity for us, most rich in sweets for Gods, Proceed thou loudly roaring on a thousand paths.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Indu, with thy streams, in might, flow for the banquet of the Gods: Rich in meath, Soma, in our beaker take thy place.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thy drops that swim in water have exalted Indra to delight: The Gods have drunk thee up for immortality.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Stream opulence to us, ye drops of Soma, pressed and purified, Pouring down rain from heaven in hoods, and finding light.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Soma, while filtered, with his wave flows through the long wool of the sheep, Shouting while purified before the voice of song.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With songs they send the Mighty forth, sporting in wood, above the fleece: Our psalms have glorified him of the triple height.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Into the jars hath he been loosed, like an impetuous steed for war, And lifting up his voice, while filtered, glided on.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Gold-hued and lovely in his course, througb tangles of the wool he flows, And pours heroic fame upon the worshippers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Flow thus, a faithful votary: the streams of meath have been effused. Thou comest to the filter, singing, from each side. Next: HYMN CVII. Soma Pavamana.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Now, being purified, flow hither through the fleece inviolate and most odorous. We ladden thee in waters when thou art effused, blending thee still with juice and milk.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Pressed out for all to see, delighting Gods, Indu, Far-sighted One, is mental power.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Cleansing thee, Soma, in thy stream, thou flowest in a watery robe: Giver of wealth, thou sittest in the place of Law, O God, a fountain made of gold.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Milking the heavenly udder for dear meath, he hath sat in the ancient gatheringplace. Washed by the men, the Strong Farseeing One streams forth nutriti us food that all desire.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Soma, while they cleanse thee, dear and watchful in the sheep's long wool, Thou hast become a Singer most like Aṅgiras: thou madest Sūrya mount to heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bountiful, best of furtherers, Soma floweth on, Ṛṣi and Singer, keen of sight. Thou hast become a Sage most welcome to the Gods: thou madest Sūrya mount to heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Pressed out by pressers, Soma goes over the fleecy backs of sheep, Goes, even as with a mare, in tawnycoloured stream, goes in exhilarating stream.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Down to the water-Soma, rich in kine hath flowed with cows, with cows that have been milked. They have approached the mixing-vessel as a sea: the cheerer streams for the carouse.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Effused by stones, O Soma, and urged through the long wool of the sheep, Thou, entering the saucers as a man the fort, gold-hued hast settled in the wood.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He beautifies himself through the sheep's long fine wool, like an impetuous steed in war, Even Soma Pavamana who shall be the joy of sages and of holy bards.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Soma,—for the feast of Gods, river-like he hath swelled with surge, With the stalk's juice, exhilarating, resting not, into the vat that drops with meath.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Like a dear son who must be decked, the Lovely One hath clad him in a shining robe. Men skilful at their work drive him forth, like a car, into the rivers from their bands.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The living drops of Soma juice pour, as they flow, the gladdening drink, Intelligent drops above the basin of the sea, exhilarating, finding light.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: May Pavamana, King and God, speed with his wave over the sea the lofty rite: May he by Mitra's and by Varuṇa's decree flow furthering the lofty rite.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Far-seeing, lovely, guided by the men, the God whose home is in the sea-

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Soma, the gladdening juice, flows pressed for Indra with his Marut host: He hastens o’er the fleece with all his thousand streams: men make him bright and beautiful.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Purified in the bowl and gendering the hymn, wise Soma joys among the Gods. Robed in the flood, the Mighty One hath clad himself with milk and settled in the vats.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Soma, Indu, every day thy friendship hath been my delight. Many fiends follow me; help me, thou Tawny-hued; pass on beyond these barriers.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Close to thy bosom am I, Soma, day and night. O Tawny-hued, for friendship sake. Sūrya himself refulgent with his glow have we o’ertaken in his course like birds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Deft-handcd! thou when purified liftest thy voice amid the sea. Thou, Pavamana, makest riches flow to us, yellow, abundant, much-desifed.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Making thee pure and bright in the sheep's long wool, thou hast bellowed, steerlike, in the wood. Thou flowest, Soma Pavamana, balmed with milk unto the special place of Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Flow on to win us strength, flow on to lofty lore of every kind. Thou, Soma, as Exhilarator wast the first to spread the sea abroad for Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Flow to the realm of earth, flow to the realm of heaven, O Soma, in thy righteous ways. Fair art thou whom the sages, O Far-seeing One, urge onward with their songs and hymns.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Over the cleansing sieve have flowed the Pavamanas in a stream, Girt by the Maruts, gladdening, Steeds with Indra's stiength, for wisdom and for dainty food.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Urged onward by the pressers, clad in watery robes, Indu is speeding to the vat. He gendering light, hath made the glad Cows low, while he takes them as his garb of state. Next: HYMN CVIII. Soma Pavamana.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: FOR Indra, flow thou Soma on, as gladdening juice most sweet, intelligent, Great, cheering, dwelling most in heaven.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, of whom having drunk the Steer acts like a steer. drinking of this that finds the light, He, Excellently Wise, is come to strengthening food, to spoil and wealth like Etaśa.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: For, verily, Pavamana, thou hast, splendidest, called all the generations of The Gods to immortality.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: By whom Dadhyac Navagva opens fastened doors, by whom the sages gained their wish, By whom they won the fame of lovely Amṛta in the felicity of Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Effused, he floweth in a stream, best rapture-giver, in the long wool of the sheep, Sporting, as ’twere the waters' wave.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He who from out the rocky cavern took with might the redmrefulgent watery Cows, Thou masterest the stable full of kine and steeds: burst it, brave Lord, like one in mail.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Press ye and pour him, like a steed, laudworthy, speeding through the region and the flood, Who swims in water, roan in wood;

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Increaser of the water, Steer with thousand streams, dear to the race of Deities; Who born in Law hath waxen mighty by the Law, King, God, and lofty Ordinance.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Make splendid glory shine on us, thou Lord of strengthening food, God, as the Friend of Gods: Unclose the fount of middle air.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Roll onward to the bowls, O Mighty One, effused, as Prince supporter of the tribes. Pour on us rain from heaven, send us the waters' flow: incite our thoughts to win the spoil.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They have drained him the Steer of heaven, him with a thousand streams, distilling rapturous joy, Him who brings all things excellent.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The Mighty One was born Immortal, giving life, lightening darkness with his shine. Wcll-praised by. sages he hath. by his wondrous power assumed the Threefold as his robe.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Effused is he who brings good things, who brings us bounteous gifts and sweet refreshing food, Soma who brings us quiet homes:

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He whom our Indra and the Marut host shall drink, Bhaga shall drink with Aryarnan, By whom we bring to us Mitra and Varuṇa and Indra for our great defence.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Soma, for Indra's drink do thou, led by the men, well-wcaponcd and most gladdening, Flow on with greatest store of sweets.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Enter the Soma-holder, even Indra's heart, as rivers pass into the sea, Acceptable to Mitra, Vāyu, Varuṇa, the noblest Pillar of the heavens. Next: HYMN CIX. Soma Pavamana.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: PLEASANT to Indra's Mitra's, Pūṣan's Bhaga's taste, sped onward, Soma, with thy flowing stream.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Let Indra drink, O Soma, of thy juice for wisdom, and all Deities for strength.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So flow thou on as bright celestial juice, flow to the vast, immortal dwelling-place.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Flow onward, Soma, as a mighty sea, as Father of the Gods to every form.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Flow on, O Soma, radiant for the Gods and Heaven and Earth and bless our progeny.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou, bright Juice, art Sustainer of the sky: flow, mighty, in accordance with true Law.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Soma, flow splendid with thy copious stream through the great fleece as in the olden time.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Bom, led by men, joyous, and purified, let the Light-finder make all blessings flow:

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indu, while cleansed, keeping the people safe, shall give us all possessions for our own.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Flow on for wisdom, Soma, and for power, as a strong courser bathed, to win the prize.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The pressers purify this juice of thine, the Soma, for delight, and lofty fame

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They deck the Gold-hued Infant, newlyborn, even Soma, Indu, in the sieve for Gods.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Fair Indu hath flowed on for rapturous joy, Sage for good fortune in the waters' lap.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He bears the beauteous name of Indra, that wherewith he overcame all demon foes.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: All Deities are wont to drink of him, pressed by the men and blent with milk and curds.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He hath flowed forth with thousand streams effused, flowed ihsough the filter and the sheep's long wool.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: With endless genial flow the Strong hath run, purified by the waters, blent with milk.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Pressed out with stones, directed by the men, go fortli, O Soma, into Indra's throat.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The mighty Soma with a thousand streams is poured to Indra through the cleansing sieve.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indu they balm with pleasant milky juice for Indra, for the Steer, for his delight.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Lightly, for sheen, they cleanse thee for the Gods, gold-coloured, wearing water as thy robe.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Indu to Indra streams, yea, downward streams, Strong, flowing to the floods, and mingling -there. Next: HYMN CX. Soma Pavamana.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O'ERPOWERING Vṛtras, forward run to win great strength: Thou speedest to subdue like one exacting debts.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In thee, effused, O Soma, we rejoice ourselves for great supremacy in fight. Thou, Pavamana, enterest into mighty deeds,

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Pavamana, thou didst generate the Sun, and spread the moisture out with power, Hasting to us with plenty vivified with milk.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Thou didst produce him, Deathless God mid mortal men for maintenance of Law and lovely Amṛta: Thou evermore hast moved making strength flow to us.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: All round about hast thou with glory pierced for us as ’twere a never-failing well for men to drink, Borne on thy way in fragments from the presser's arms.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Then, beautifully radiant, certain Heavenly Ones, have sung to him their kinship as they looked thereon, And Savitar the God opens as ’twere a stall.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Soma, the men of old whose grass was trimmed addressed the hymn to thee for mighty strength and for renown: So, Hero, urge us onward to heroic power.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: They have drained forth from out the great depth of the sky the old primeval milk of heaven that claims the laud: They lifted up their voice to Indra athis birth.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: As long as thou, O Pavamana, art above this earth and heaven and all existence in thy might, Thou standest like a Bull the chief amid the herd.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: In the sheep's wool hath Soma Pavamana flowed, while they cleanse him, like a playful infant, Indu with hundred powers and hundred currents.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Holy and sweet, while purified, this Indu flows on, a wave of pleasant taste, to Indra,— Strength-winner, Treasure-finder, Life. bestower.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: So flow thou on, subduing our assailants, chasing the demons hard to beencountered, Well-armed and conquering our foes, O Soma. Next: HYMN CXI. Soma Pavamana.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WITH this his golden splendour purifying him, he with his own allies subdues all enemies, as Sara with his own allies. Cleansing himself with stream of juice he shines forth yellow-hued and red, when with the praisers he encompasses all forms, with praisers having seven mouths.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: That treasure of the Paṇis thou discoveredst; thou with thy mothers deckest thee in thine abode, with songs of worship in thine home. As ’twere from far, the hymn is heard, where holy songs resound in joy. He with the ruddy-hued, threefold hath won life-power, he, glittering, hath won life-power.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: He moves intelligent, directed to the East. The very beauteous car rivals the beams of light, the beautiful celestial car. Hymns, lauding manly valour, came, inciting Indra to success, that ye may be unconquered, both thy bolt and thou, both be unconquered in the war. Next: HYMN CXII. Soma Pavamana.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: WE all have various thoughts and plans, and diverse are the ways of men. The Brahman seeks the worshipper, wright seeks the cracked, and leech the maimed. Flow, Indu, flow for Indra's sake.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The smith with ripe and seasoned plants, with feathers of the birds of air, With stones, and with enkindled flames, seeks him who hath a store of gold. Flow, Indu, flow for Indra's sake.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: A bard am I, my dad's a leech, mammy lays corn upon the stones. Striving for wealth, with varied plans, we follow our desires like kine. Flow, Indu, flow for Indra's sake.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: The horse would draw an easy car, gay hosts attract the laugh and jest. The male desires his mate's approach, the frog is eager for the flood, Flow, Indu, flow for Indra's sake. Next: HYMN CXIII. Soma Pavamana.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: LET Vṛtra-slaying Indra drink Soma by Śaryaṇāvān's side, Storing up vigour in his heart, prepared to do heroic deeds. Flow, Indu, flow for Indra's sake.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Lord of the Quarters, flow thou on, boon Soma, from Arjika land, Effused with ardour and with faith, and the true hymn of sacrifice. Flow, Indu, flow for Indra's sake.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Hither hath Sūrya's Daughter brought the wild Steer whom Parjanya nursed. Gandharvas have seized bold of him, and in the Soma laid the juice. Flow, Indu, flow for Indra's sake.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Splendid by Law! declaring Law, truthspeaking, truthful in thy works, Enouncing faith, King Soma! thou, O Soma, whom thy maker decks. Flow, Indu, flow for Indra's sake.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Together flow the meeting streams of him the Great and truly Strong. The juices of the juicy meet. Made pure by prayer, O Golden-hued, flow, Indu, flow for Indra's sake.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Pavamana, where the priest, as he recites the rhythmic prayer, Lords it o’er Soma with the stone, with Soma bringing forth delight, flow, Indu, flow for Indra's sake.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: O Pavarnana, place me in that deathless, undecaying world Wherein the light of heaven is set, and everlasting lustre shines. Flow, Indu, flow for Indra's sake.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Make me immortal in that realm where dwells the King, Vivasvān's Son, Where is the secret shrine of heaven, where are those waters young and fresh. Flow, Indu, flow for Indra's sake.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Make me immortal in that realm where they move even as they list, In the third sphere of inmost heaven where lucid worlds are full of light. Flow, Indu, flow for Indra's sake.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Make me immortal in that realm of eager wish and strong desire, The region of the radiant Moon, where food and full delight are found. Flow, Indu, flow for Indra's sake:

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Make me immortal in that realm where happiness and transports, where Joys and felicities combine, and longing wishes are fulfilled. Flow, Indu, flow for Indra's sake. Next: HYMN CXIV. Soma Pavamana.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: THE man who waIketh as the Laws of Indu Pavamana bid,— Men call him rich in children, him, O Soma, who hath met thy thought. Flow, Indu, flow for Indra's sake.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Kasyapa, Ṛṣi, lifting up thy voice with hymn-composers' lauds, Pav reverence to King Soma born the Sovran Ruler of the plants. Flow, Indu, flow for Indra's sake.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Seven regions have their several Suns; the ministering priests are seven; Seven are the Āditya Deities,—with these, O Soma, guard thou us. Flow, Indu, flow for Indra's sake.

translator: R. T. H. Griffith — Public Domain
text: Guard us with this oblation which, King Soma, hath been dressed for thee. Next: HYMN I. Agni.
